column4: Is there a power save option that disables compiz automatically when I'm running on battery?
If not, wouldn't that make sense?
I would imagine it is possible. You'd have to look for the script and add that to the command. I'd suggest for you to write your own script, that way, you can add/remove more than just compiz.
guess it wouldn't be that hard to write. But in my opinion this 'script' should be added to the powersave options

You can request for it on Ubuntu Brainstorm. I recall somebody requesting the power manager to have "Do Nothing" feature too.  Also, to disable compiz to shave few minutes off? While you're at it, two gnome-panels is using more processes than one gnome-panel. You get the idea.
sorry don't understand the last gnome-panel part.
Do you use htop? There are a list of processes that you probably does not need to have it running such as gnome-screensaver. I have that package uninstalled.
Do you think disabling compiz while I'm on battery really would save me only a very few minutes?
I don't know. I like having compiz running. You would have to do a trial run. :)
Have you thought about buying extended battery cells? I have one for my netbook. I don't really know its battery life but I have seen "10 hours" and I don't know if I want to believe that. :o
:) Well maybe it would not bad to have an "advanced" power management. Mean not only compiz to control with but multiple apps and services or gnome-panels
nah I'm fine with my 8 hours ;) was just an idea :)

It is easier to write a script.  There are only few parameters. That way, you could do "metacity --replace, killall <processes>, that's about it."  Eventually, you might realized you don't really need few processes in first place and started to weed them out.
Sure one should start with erasing programs or services that are not needed.
script is fine. It is just: power managemnt already has t check if I'm on battery or not, so it would be nice if compiz switcher could work on top of that acpi or however it is called
http://projects.gnome.org/gnome-power-manager/ + http://live.gnome.org/GnomeScreensaver/ -- You might have some luck finding out how to run scripts after certain events.
